body: Looks like core/TEST005 failed. There are two queries in that test that look at the query cache. That behavior might have changed due to your change. If this is true, you'll need to update the expected results for that test also.
Thanks Dave, I run this on my workstation, it passed the test005. but run again, yes, it failed. Let me update the expect file, and have a new try.
Please don't merge this yet. I am working on seabase/TEST031 failure seen with this change

Sorry this conversation  never got to me - a mail glitch. Most of the changes in LOB are in JDBC so @orrk should verify them.   Ther is one issue that has already been foudn and pointed out by Steve and mentioned in the original JIRA as the last comment. This needs to be corrected in Master branch : https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TRAFODION-2740
jenkins, retest -- testing new jenkins automation for checktests

Unfortunately, non-deterministic functions like RAND() don't work very well in SQL. The documentation needs to mention that. From the current text, it sounds like we guarantee a certain behavior, such as that select RAND(), RAND(), RAND() will give independent values. That may not be true in all situations.

Another example: select * from t where a < RAND(). I can't define what this query means. Do we evaluate RAND() once per query or once per row?

At the least we need a warning in this section that RAND() does not always behaves in predictable ways.

We had this problem with other functions as well. See also TRAFODION-2954, https://github.com/apache/trafodion/pull/1444, TRAFODION-2912.

Ignore this latest test failure.  It was just a glitch in jdbc job that passed previously.  I was using this PR as a guinea pig for update of jenkins automation to prove checktest1 and checktest2 jobs are working.
Please do not merge this in yet; I will be running full regressions on a workstation with these changes overnight.

@zellerh Thanks for your review :)

1. I've run a test and found that the RAND function is evaluated per row (see example below). 
Can I add this to manual?

```
SQL>SELECT * FROM t1;
C1          C2         
----------- -----------
          1           2
          2           2
          3           2
          4           2
          5           2
--- 5 row(s) selected.

SQL>SELECT c1, c2 FROM t1 WHERE c2 < MOD(RAND(),5);
C1          C2         
----------- -----------
          2           2
          5           2
--- 2 row(s) selected.

SQL>SELECT c1, c2 FROM t1 WHERE c2 < MOD(RAND(),5);
C1          C2         
----------- -----------
          2           2
          4           2
--- 2 row(s) selected.

SQL>SELECT c1, c2 FROM t1 WHERE c2 < MOD(RAND(),5);
--- 0 row(s) selected.

SQL>SELECT c1, c2 FROM t1 WHERE c2 < MOD(RAND(),5);
C1          C2         
----------- -----------
          3           2
          4           2
--- 2 row(s) selected.
```

2. Yes, I found that some results are not same as expected, they are regularly changed (see example below), so I delete the first example in the manual and add a NOTE based on your comments.
```
SQL>SELECT RAND(1), RAND(10), RAND(50), RAND(100), RAND(150), RAND(200), RAND(1000) FROM DUAL;

(EXPR)     (EXPR)     (EXPR)     (EXPR)     (EXPR)     (EXPR)     (EXPR)    
---------- ---------- ---------- ---------- ---------- ---------- ----------
     16807     168070     840350    1680700    2521050    3361400   16807000

--- 1 row(s) selected.
```
Do not merge. Both the Jenkins run and my full regression run show some plan changes that need to be analyzed. I will likely submit additional changes.
I think you should add license header into new java files.

The reworks do the following:

1. Update expected results for compGeneral/TEST015. One query plan changed from hash semi join to hash join + group by. I did a performance test of both plans; their execution time average is almost the same.

2. Change the small inner table criterion to fire only if statistics exist on the inner table. (I had meant to do this originally and simply forgot.)

3. Update comments in Join::transformSemiJoin per @zellerh 's suggestions.
Previous Test Aborted. New Check Test Started: https://jenkins.esgyn.com/job/Check-PR-master/2585/

Can you explain a bit how this will work at the JDBC interface level? Will a user pass a statement like this to Connection::prepareStatement:

```
conn.prepareStatement("begin insert into t1 values(?,?); delete from t2; insert into t2 values (?); end");
```

If/when we resurrect the Trafodion code to support compound statements, will the interface work the same?

I am not clear on the application interface to support this feature. Are we trying to conform to mysql way as given in this link https://stackoverflow.com/questions/10797794/multiple-queries-executed-in-java-in-single-statement

@mashengchen, I was thinking of a compound statement in my example. Your reply and the link that @selvaganesang provided helped me understand better. Trying to summarize what I heard, what you are implementing is a way to run multiple statements, in the following way:

- Users need to specify an option in the connection string to enable this feature.
- Users need to specify multiple statements, separated by semicolons (no begin/end block).
- This feature does not implement a compound statement (begin end block).

If that's true, then that sounds ok to me. I just wanted to make sure we can add compound statements like in MySQL or IBM DB2 later without running into trouble with your feature.
@zellerh it's right in your summary, this PR is just a simple implement of the feature, the fully implement should change the sql engine code, which i am not familiar with it.
